# DataVisTools Functions Documentation

## InteractivePlot()

### Purpose:

The InteractivePlot function generates interactive plots using Plotly, allowing users to explore data interactively. It accepts a dataframe as input and produces an interactive plot based on user-defined specifications.

### Inputs:

-   **data**: A dataframe containing the data to be plotted.
-   **x**: The variable to be plotted on the x-axis.
-   **y**: The variable to be plotted on the y-axis.
-   **type**: The type of plot to be generated (e.g., scatter, line, bar).
-   **color**: Optional parameter specifying the color of the plot points or lines.
-   **title**: Optional parameter to set the title of the plot.

### Outputs:

An interactive Plotly plot object that can be embedded in web pages or viewed in RStudio.

### Example:

\`\`\`r library(DataVisTools)

# Create sample dataframe

data \<- data.frame( x = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5), y = c(10, 15, 13, 18, 20) )

# Generate interactive scatter plot

InteractivePlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", type = "scatter", color = "blue", title = "Interactive Scatter Plot")

CustomizePlot() Purpose: The CustomizePlot function allows users to customize plot aesthetics, including colors, labels, titles, and annotations. It provides flexibility in adjusting the visual appearance of plots generated by DataVisTools functions.

Inputs: plot: The plot object to be customized. title: Optional parameter to set the title of the plot. x_label: Optional parameter to set the label for the x-axis. y_label: Optional parameter to set the label for the y-axis. color: Optional parameter specifying the color of plot elements (e.g., points, lines). annotations: Optional parameter to add annotations to the plot. Outputs: A customized plot object with user-defined aesthetics.

Example:

library(DataVisTools)

# Create sample plot

plot \<- ggplot(data = iris, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Sepal.Width, color = Species)) + geom_point()

# Customize plot aesthetics

CustomizePlot(plot, title = "Customized Scatter Plot", x_label = "Sepal Length", y_label = "Sepal Width", color = "blue") HistogramPlot() Purpose: The HistogramPlot function generates histograms to visualize the distribution of a numeric variable. It provides insights into the central tendency, variability, and skewness of the data.

Inputs: data: A dataframe containing the data to be plotted. x: The variable to be plotted. bins: Optional parameter specifying the number of bins for the histogram. color: Optional parameter specifying the color of the histogram bars. title: Optional parameter to set the title of the plot. Outputs: A histogram plot object depicting the distribution of the specified variable.

Example:

library(DataVisTools)

# Create sample dataframe

data \<- data.frame( x = rnorm(100) )

# Generate histogram plot

HistogramPlot(data, x = "x", bins = 20, color = "green", title = "Histogram of Random Data") GeospatialPlot() Purpose: The GeospatialPlot function enables users to create geospatial visualizations by plotting data points on geographic maps. It provides insights into spatial patterns and relationships within the data.

Inputs: data: A dataframe containing the spatial data to be plotted. longitude: The variable representing longitude coordinates. latitude: The variable representing latitude coordinates. color: Optional parameter specifying the color of the data points. title: Optional parameter to set the title of the plot. Outputs: A geospatial plot object displaying data points on a map.

Example:

library(DataVisTools)

# Create sample dataframe

data \<- data.frame( city = c("New York", "Los Angeles", "Chicago"), longitude = c(-74.006, -118.243, -87.629), latitude = c(40.7128, 34.0522, 41.8781) )

# Generate geospatial plot

GeospatialPlot(data, longitude = "longitude", latitude = "latitude", color = "red", title = "Cities Map")
